abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Agro-Pastoral Export
            Promotion Project for Niger were as follows: the outcome was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was negligible, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: A series of in-depth
            analyses of the selected sub-sectors should be conducted as
            part of project preparation to identify the key obstacles
            towards improved export performance. In integrated value
            chain approach should be adopted from the out start whereby
            support is provided to the different stakeholders in each
            selected sub-sector to develop and agree on a comprehensive
            strategy for achieving export growth. Grant support should
            be primarily for support services; grant support for
            physical investment should be provided only in cases where
            operators further down the value chain are unable to obtain
            financing from other sources. Project management should be
            contracted out to an independent team of experts who have
            been given decision making authority based on a detailed
            procedures manual, with ex-post controls by the Government.
            A rigorous monitoring and evaluation system should be
            developed as part of project preparation with as key
            element. It should be recognized that some value chains will
            require substantial private investment to achieve their full
            export potential. In future matching grant schemes,
            alternative means for managing grant resources need to be
            looked at including the possibility of contracting out the
            management of the scheme.
